occurrences.line_text: So deepely dinted in the driuen clay,
And shooting in the earth, casts vp a mount of clay.
The images of God in earthly clay;
A lesson too too hard for liuing clay,
Are wont to cleaue vnto the lowly clay,
At last he thus; Thou clod of vilest clay,
Nor shining gold, nor mouldring clay it was;
To sperre the gate; but that same lumpe of clay,
By such, as claymd themselues Brutes rightfull haires,
Her claym'd, by him in battell wonne long sens:
Vpon your seas, he claym'd as propertie:
And wield the world, she claymed for her syre,
The Cle, the Were, the Grant, the Sture, the Rowne.
All cleane dismayd to see so vncouth sight,
Were cleane consum'd, and all his vitall powres
And guilt of sinfull crimes cleane wash away,
And the cleane waues with purple gore did ray;
striue her to banish cleane.
The drops dry vp, and filth wipe cleane away:
Saue one old Nymph, hight Panope to keepe it cleane.
Now vanisht vtterly, and cleane subuerst
And the still Darent, in whose waters cleane
And in the sight of all men cleane disgraced,
And cleane were gone, which way he neuer knew;
For all his washing cleaner. Still he stroue,
Yet nothing cleaner were for such intent,
Who by her cleanly garment catching hold,
Right cleanly clad in comely sad attire;
Albe her guiltlesse conscience her cleard,
But cleard that stripling of th'imputed blame,
Adornd with gold and iewels shining cleare,
Drunke of the streame, as cleare as cristall glas;
For well she wist, his crime could else be neuer cleare.
My conscience cleare with guilty bands would bind?
That cleare she dide from blemish criminall;
As morning Sunne her beames dispredden cleare,
Cleare the deawy ayre with springing light,
At last they heard a horne, that shrilled cleare
Cleare as the skie, withouten blame or blot,
He heard a voice, that called loud and cleare,
And with her light the earth enlumines cleare;
Till that at last the weather gan to cleare,
Few drops, more cleare then Nectar, forth distild,
Whose face did seeme as cleare as Christall stone,
That the bright glister of their beames cleare
Into a cleare Carnation suddeine dyde;
The face of heauen, and the cleare aire engrost,
On which the winged boy in colours cleare
Quite ouerblowne, yet doth not passe so cleare,
And euermore sought Britomart to cleare.
Amongst the lesser starres in euening cleare.
To frame such subtile wire, so shinie cleare.
Whose eyes like twinkling stars in euening cleare,
The sunne at length his ioyous face doth cleare:
Then in the sunshine of her countenance cleare
Against him iustifie, and proue her cleare
How cleare I am from blame of this vpbraide:
So when that Knight from perill cleare was freed,
Whose goodly light then Phebus lampe doth shine more cleare?
Sith his own thought he knew most cleare from wite.
Albe they worthy blame, or cleare of crime:
For th'aire was milde, and cleared was the skie,
His cleared heart eftsoones away gan chace
More then my former writs, all were they clearest
How oft do they with golden pineons, cleaue
And all his seed the curse doth often cleaue,
His owne good sword Morddure, to cleaue his head.
Are wont to cleaue vnto the lowly clay,
But it would pierce or cleaue, where so it came;
And with her pineons cleaues the liquid firmament.
And cleauing the hard steele, did deepe inuade
But all of Diamond perfect pure and cleene
From whence the riuer Dee as siluer cleene
And that bright towre all built of christall cleene,
His shackles emptie left, him selfe escaped cleene.
Layd first his filthy hands on virgin cleene,
His guiltie hands from bloudie gore to cleene,
That dyde in sanguine red her skin all snowy cleene.
And from her partie eftsoones was drawen cleene.
By her strong foe, who had defaced cleene
And cleeped him his liege, to hold of him in fee.
That of them cleeped was the Lady of delight.
Concord she cleeped was in common reed,
Into old Gall, that now is cleeped France,
Sir Sanglier; (so cleeped was that Knight)
Therefore it rightly cleeped was mount Acidale.
And cleft his head. He tumbling downe aliue,
Washing his bloudy wounds, that through the steele were cleft.
Of his huge taile he quite a sunder cleft,
Vnto her boat againe, with which she cleft
Haue cleft his head in twaine, and life thence dispossest.
That to the chin he cleft his head in twaine:
His weasand pipe it through his gorget cleft:
It would haue cleft his braine downe to his brest.
It would haue cleft him to the girding place,
As they the cliffe in peeces would haue cleft;
She with one stroke both head and helmet cleft.
Ne ought could them endure, but all they cleft or brast.
And cleft his head asunder to his chin.
Vnplough'D, the which my coulter hath not cleft:
To shew that clemence oft in things amis,
And his auenging wrath to clemencie incline.
Of courteous clemencie in gentle hart.
The sacred pledge of peace and clemencie,
And worthie paterns of her clemencies;
Seauen women by him slaine, and eaten clene.
Sate goodly Temperance in garments clene,
For his owne turne, yet inly neate and clene,
Babes bloudie hands may not be clensd,
May not be clensd with water of this well:
High minded Cleopatra, that with stroke
The worlds whole rule for Cleopatras sight.
Whose kingdomes seat Cleopolis is red,
That great Cleopolis, where I haue beene,
Yet is Cleopolis for earthly frame,
Cleopolis foundation first of all:
Except Cleopolis: so heard I say
That cleped was Port Esquiline, whereby
Therefore he Anamnestes cleped is,
The other cleped Cruelty by name:
Whom such when as Malbecco spyed clere,
And all mankinde do nourish with their waters clere.
But since it me concernes, my selfe to clere,
For beautie is more glorious bright and clere,
Her tender sides, her bellie white and clere,
And to the Clergy now was come at last;
The kitchin Clerke, that hight Digestion,
Eftsoones vntwisting his deceiptfull clew,
And alwaies in her hand two clewes of silke she twynd.
Vnder the hanging of an hideous clieffe,
But chaunced on a craggy cliff to light;
As they the cliffe in peeces would haue cleft;
So downe the cliffe the wretched Gyant tumbled;
And dauncing on the craggy cliffes at will;
His goodly corps on ragged cliffs yrent,
And throwne about the cliffs. Arriued there,
High growing on the top of rocky clift,
Farre vnderneath a craggie clift ypight,
So downe he fell, as an huge rockie clift,
Whiles sad Celeno, sitting on a clift,
Like an huge caue, hewne out of rocky clift,
Of mightie Magnes stone, whose craggie clift
Which still sate waiting on that wastfull clift,
On whose sharpe clifts the ribs of vessels broke,
That gainst the craggy clifts did loudly rore,
That through the clifts the vermeil bloud out sponne,
Then all the rest into their coches clim,
In hast was climbing vp the Easterne hill,
To clime aloft, and others to excell:
That was so high, as foe might not it clime,
And eke attonce the heauy trees they clime,
The sonne of Climene he did repent,
Begin, ï¿½ Clio, and recount from hence
Ile clip his wanton wings, that he no more shall fly.
Tho fast her clipping twixt his armes twaine,
Lightly he clipt her twixt his armes twaine,
Or as the Moone cloathed with clowdy night,
Then couering with a clod their closed eye,
At last he thus; Thou clod of vilest clay,
He nould be clogd. So had he serued many one.
Yet still he stroue to cloke his inward bale,
To cloke her guile with sorrow and sad teene;
Thenceforth she sought for helps, to cloke her crime withall.
To cloke the cause, that hath it selfe bewrayd?
So courage lent a cloke to cowardise.
Now glooming sadly, so to cloke her matter;
To cloke the mischiefe, which he inly ment,
The false Duessa, cloked with Fidessaes name.
Of this false footman, clokt with simplenesse,
And asked, to what end they clomb that tedious height.
Which to behold, he clomb vp to the banke,
Tho to their ready Steeds they clombe full light,
She to her wagon clombe; clombe all the rest,
She to her wagon clombe; clombe all the rest,
And clombe vnto his steed. So forth he went,
Vnto his lofty steede he clombe anone,
By sweet Clonmell, adornes rich Waterford;
Wherein were closd few drops of liquor pure,
So shedding many teares, they closd the earth againe.
So in I past, and streight he closd the gate.
He with him closd, and laying mightie hold
And with fresh clay did close the wooden wound:
At last in close hart shutting vp her paine,
So lay him in her charet, close in night concealed.
Close couched on the beuer, seem'd to throw
So creeping close, as Snake in hidden weedes,
Close creeping twixt the marrow and the skin.
Close vnder his left wing, then broad displayd.
And comming close to Trompart gan inquere
How they within their fouldings close enwrapped bee.
Whereby close fire into his heart does creepe:
Some by close shouldring, some by flatteree;
Doubly disparted, it did locke and close,
And when it opened, no man might it close,
Was close conuaid, and to the back-gate brought,
Close round about her tuckt with many a plight:
And keepes in couerts close from liuing wight,
That in the secret of your hart close lyes,
Through many couert groues, and thickets close,
And snatching his bright sword began to close
Did spred it selfe, and venime close inspire.
Her crafty engins to her close intent.
Where feeling one close couched by her side,
Where they in secret counsell close conspird,
Litle she weend, that loue he close concealed;
But in close bowre her mewes from all mens sight,
And sent close messages of loue to her at will.
With speaking lookes, that close embassage bore,
By such close signes they secret way did make
That Cupid selfe it seeing, close did smyle,
And bearing with him treasure in close store,
Which houed close vnder a forrest side,
And in his eare him rounded close behind:
Yet afterwards close creeping, as he might,
That creeping close, amongst the hiues to reare
Hath in a dungeon deepe her close embard,
Wouen with gold and silke so close and nere,
Twixt both his hands few sparkes he close did straine,
And gan therefore close spight to him to beare:
Thus as they marched all in close disguise,
With doubled force close vnderneath his shield,
With point of steele, that close his hartbloud spild,
That through the seame, which did his hauberk close,
Close vnderneath his shield, that scarce did show,
The eyes of all, allur'd with close delight,
Now cuffling close, now chacing to and fro,
And to the Queene of beautie close did call,
When gentle sleepe his heauie eyes would close;
But Artegall close smyling ioy'd in secret hart.
With that she heard some one close by her side
Which close appeard in that rude brutishnesse,
From powrefull eyes close venim doth conuay
But being in, Delay in close awaite
A beuie of fayre damzels close did lye,
He saw no way, but close with him in hast;
Keeping there close with him in pretious store
Stood in the preasse close couered, well aduewed,
And mailes betweene, and laced close afore:
Conceiued close in her beguiled hart,
Her selfe there close afflicted long in vaine,
He should his purpose misse, which close he ment:
Of armed men, comming with close intent
And with sweete rest her heauy eyes did close,
A wondrous vision, which did close implie
Yet still the Prince pursew'd him close behind,
That from close friends, that dar'd not to appeare,
That Tyrants part, with close or open ayde,
And couching close his speare and all his powre,
Hauing by chaunce a close aduantage vew'd,
That all about did close the compasse of his eye.
Contagious poyson close through euery vaine,
But ioyning close, huge lode at him did lay:
He watcht in close awayt with weapons prest,
Gan mutter close a certaine secret charme,
And ioyed long in close felicity:
Vnto their dwelling did them close conuay.
But Calidore in th'entry close did stand,
Then couering with a clod their closed eye,
Still open to their friends, and closed to their foes.
I mote haue closed, and him bed farewell,
Either fast closed in some hollow greaue,
For to efforce, when charmes had closed it afore.
Was closed vp, as it had not bene bor'd,
The Lists were closed fast, to barre the rout
Where that false couple were full closely ment
Did closely lurke; yet so true-seeming grace
His wandring perill closely did lament,
His warlike shield all closely couer'd was,
Was warie wise, and closely did awayt
Them closely into Armorick did beare:
In strong entrenchments he did closely place,
He daintie couch with teares, which closely she did weepe.
Was taken with her loue, and by her closely lay.
Mongst whom might be, that he did closely lye,
Closely the wicked flame his bowels brent,
Her wearie Palfrey closely, as she might,
Gainst Britomart, and euer closely eyde
So closely yet, that none but she it vewed,
He closely nearer crept, the truth to weet:
So closely as he could, he to them crept,
She slept, yet twixt her eyelids closely spyde,
Did closely with a cruell one consent,
Which all that while I closely had conceld;
But closely rankled vnder th'orifis:
Did closely harbour such a iealous guest)
They in awayt would closely him ensnarle,
Appear'd like Aspis sting, that closely kils,
And closely hid her selfe within the groue.
The more he laughes, and does her closely quip,
And closely tempted with their craftie spyes;
Thereat frown'd Coridon, and his lip closely bit.
And all his paines did closely emulate;
But he, that in his mind had closely made
And closely did her wed, but knowne to few.
In the deare closet of her painefull side,
Into her fathers closet to repayre;
She to his closet went, where all his wealth
Within the closet of her couert brest:
That it the Posterne did from closing stay:
But closing it againe like as before,
Vntill the closure of the Euening.
High aboue all a cloth of State was spred,
Which in that cloth was wrought, as if it liuely grew.
Royally clad (quoth he) in cloth of gold,
And cloth in womens weedes: And then with threat
All ouer her a cloth of state was spred,
Not of rich tissew, nor of cloth of gold,
The cloth of state, and on their purpled wings
In a greene gowne he clothed was full faire,
He clothed was, ypainted full of eyes;
Clothed with leaues, that none the wood mote see
And clothed all in garments made of line,
For other clothes he could not weare for heat,
But clothes meet to keepe keene could away,
In Claribellaes clothes. Her proper face
With costly clothes of Arras and of Toure,
The clothes about her round with busie ayd;
Ordained hath, he clothes with sinfull mire,
That her gay clothes did in discolour die.
Of clothes to couer, what they ought by kind:
Sad Clotho held the rocke, the whiles the thrid
Which Clotho graunting, shewed her the same:
And if that no spare cloths to giue he had,
Euer to come into his clouch againe,
Or in the compasse of his clouches tooke;
A cloud of combrous gnattes do him molest,
The cloud of death did sit. Which doen away,
Couering your foe with cloud of deadly night,
Lay couer'd with inchaunted cloud all day:
Couerd with charmed cloud from vew of day,
His blushing face in foggy cloud implyes,
Through smouldry cloud of duskish stincking smoke,
As when a cloud his beames doth ouer-lay;
A cloud of smoothering smoke and sulphur seare
That round about a cloud of dust did fly,
That as a cloud doth seeme to dim the skies;
From whence it doth, as cloud from sea arise.
Is in a noyous cloud enueloped,
Couered with secret cloud of silent night,
There a sad cloud of sleepe her ouerkest,
That in a cloud their light did long time stay,
Faire heauen with an vniuersall cloud,
Like as a gloomie cloud, the which doth beare
A watry cloud doth ouercast the skie,
To cloud my daies in dolefull misery,
Hath in a watry cloud displayed wide
For though this cloud haue now me ouercast,
But like a cloud, as likest may be told,
Who with a cloud of night him couering, bore
But enuies cloud still dimmeth vertues ray.
With cloud of death vpon her eyes displayd;
Yet did the cloud make euen that dimmed light
The day with cloudes was suddeine ouercast,
Through riuen cloudes and molten firmament;
The cloudes before him fled for terrour great,
That vanisht into smoke and cloudes swift;
Hath him befalne, but cloudes of deadly night
The cloudes, as things affrayd, before him flye;
Like to thicke cloudes, that threat a stormy showre,
Couered with cloudes, her Pilot hath dismayd;
Couered with cloudie storme and bitter showre,
Enwrapt in coleblacke clouds and filthy smoke,
As lump of lead, and made darke clouds appeare;
Enwrapped in fowle smoke and clouds more blacke then Iet.
Or of the clouds to moysten their roots dry;
The soring clouds into sad showres ymolt;
Which rould in clouds to heauen did aspire,
Thee goddesse, thee the winds, the clouds doe feare,
Breathing out clouds of sulphure fowle and blacke,
Through the thicke clouds, in which they steeped lay
Like a sweet Angell twixt two clouds vphild:
When foggy mistes, or cloudy tempests haue
More hidden are, then Sunne in cloudy vele;
And into diuerse doubt his wauering wonder cloue.
That quite it cloue his plumed crest in tway,
Had he not stouped so, he should haue clouen bee.
He had him surely clouen quite in twaine.
That Colin Clout should pipe as one most fit;
Poore Colin Clout (who knowes not Colin Clout?)
Poore Colin Clout (who knowes not Colin Clout?)
His garment nought but many ragged clouts,
But since faire Sunne hath sperst that lowring clowd,
Him to haue slaine; when loe a darkesome clowd
Or as the Moone cloathed with clowdy night,
Her clowdy care into a wrathfull stowre,
Against the silly clowne, who dead through feare,
Such homely what, as serues the simple clowne,
Ne mote wylde beastes, ne mote the ruder clowne
That seem'd to be some sorie simple clowne,
But with his clownish hands their tender wings
And bruze with clownish fistes his manly face:
And in his clownish hand a sharp bore speare he shooke.
Which with his cruell tuske him deadly cloyd:
With sight whereof soone cloyd, and long deluded
Into their cloysters now he broken had,
And lifting vp his dreadfull club on hight,
His boystrous club, so buried in the ground,
With which his hideous club aloft he dites,
In his right hand an yron club he held,
His harmefull club he gan to hurtle hye,
But with his craggy club in his right hand,
And with his club me threatned to haue brayned,
And monstrous tyrants with his club subdewed;
The club of Iustice dread, with kingly powre endewed.
For his huge club, which had subdew'd of old
Vnder Alcides club, streight tooke his flight
And in his hand a mighty yron club he bore.
And with his yron club to ground him strooke;
Vnder that villaines club, then surely thought
But with his yron club preparing way,
And with his club bet backe his brondyron bright
And with his club him all about so blist,
Vnder his club with wary boldnesse went,
And whiles he stroue his combred clubbe to quight
Some with vnweldy clubs, some with long speares,
And cluster thicke vnto his leasings vaine,
Of flyes vpon a birchen bough doth cluster,
And like a sort of Bees in clusters swarmed:
Whiles in the aire their clustring army flies,
Clymbe to her charet, all with flowers spred;
So forth she comes, and to her coche does clyme,
Vnto the type of kingdomes title clymes.
Then first the coale of kindly heat appeares
But as a coale to kindle fleshly flame,
But to the easterne coast of heauen makes speedy way.
From euery coast that heauen walks about,
With either of those knights on euen coast,
Vnder what coast of heauen the man did dwell,
First from one coast, till nought thereof be drie;
From euery coast and countrie vnder sunne:
Towards which coast her loue his way addrest.
Tho when they came to the sea coast, they found
That in one day they with the coast did fall;
So towardes them they coasted, to enquire
To skim those coastes, for bondmen there to buy,
His owne coate he would cut, and it distribute glad.
Like plated coate of steele, so couched neare,
His yron coate all ouergrowne with rust,
And thred-bare cote, and cobled shoes he ware,
Eftsoones out of her Coch she gan auaile,
Vnto her Coch remounting, home did ride,
The royall Dame, and for her coche doth call:
So forth she comes, and to her coche does clyme,
Then all the rest into their coches clim,
Haue care, I pray, to guide the cock-bote well,
And now the crowing Cocke, and now the Owle
At which Cocytus quakes, and Styx is put to flight.
That is the riuer of Cocytus deepe,
Where by the grim floud of Cocytus slow
Then said the aged Coelia, Deare dame,
And came to Coelia to declare her smart,
So leaue they take of Coelia, and her daughters three.
And there before them stood a Coffer strong,
She chaunst vnwares to light vppon this coffer,
Yet in this coffer, which she with her brought,
Two iron coffers hong on either side,
But huge great yron chests and coffers strong,
The coffers of her wicked threasury;
Eft soones of him had perfect cognizance,
And in his lap an heape of coine he told;
Or fell Medea, when on Colchicke strand
For though a tree I seeme, yet cold and heat me paines.
Who full of ghastly fright and cold affray,
The creeping deadly cold away did shake:
That suddein cold did runne through euery vaine,
Till crudled cold his corage gan assaile,
Now let the stony dart of senselesse cold
The carefull cold beginneth for to creepe,
Him to auenge, before his bloud were cold,
Paine, hunger, cold, that makes the hart to quake;
The crudled cold ran to her well of life,
That sight thereof bred cold congealed feare:
Himselfe refreshing with the liquid cold,
And his fresh bloud did frieze with fearefull cold,
And to her said; Yet if the stony cold
Yet cold through feare, and old conceiued dreads;
Nor sea of licour cold, nor lake of mire,
Cold Coloquintida, and Tetra mad,
Of the cold liquor, which he waded in,
Vile is the vengeance on the ashes cold,
Now seeming flaming whot, now stony cold.
All naked without shame, or care of cold,
Thereto as cold and drery as a Snake,
Nor scorching heat, nor cold intemperate
And shewd him many sights, that courage cold could reare.
To doe the frosen cold away to fly;
The cold earth was his couch, the hard steele his pillow.
She with her scarfe did bind the wound fro[m] cold to keepe.
After her heat the breathing cold to taste;
For her faint heart was with the frozen cold
Whiles the cold ysickles from his rough beard,
And Troynouant was built of old Troyes ashes cold.
Were ouerthrowne and layd on th'earth full cold,
Which in his cold complexion do breed
There on the cold earth him now thrown she found,
As fayning choler, which was turn'd to cold:
Then all that euening welcommed with cold,
Her graunted loue, but with affection cold
Began to faint, and feele their corage cold.
Cold yron chaines, with which let him be tide;
